entry.title: Combined summary - Motion to Activate BIP 3
entry.summary: In March 2025, the Bitcoin Improvement Proposal (BIP) 3 was advanced to a "Proposed" status and has since seen multiple minor adjustments aimed at its improvement. A significant milestone in the proposal's journey is the ongoing maintenance of an active pull request on GitHub, specifically [pull request 1820](https://github.com/bitcoin/bips/pull/1820), which has attracted considerable attention from the community. This pull request has become a focal point for discussion, garnering over 600 comments and sparking extensive debate across various threads on the Bitcoin Development Mailing List. The community's support for BIP 3 is evident, with many individuals endorsing the proposal through their acknowledgments on the pull request. The proposition to supersede BIP 2 with BIP 3 highlights a need for a more specified procedure for activating Process BIPs, addressing gaps within the current BIP 2 framework. Key modifications to BIP 3 include the adoption of SPDX License Expressions for the License header, removing the License-Code header in favor of directory-specific licensing terms, and renaming the "Created" header to "Assigned." These changes aim to refine the BIP text to better articulate the purpose of the BIPs repository, encourage author validation of proposals via the mailing list, and clarify the publication, acceptance, and adoption processes of proposals. Furthermore, it addresses the closure of Draft BIPs due to lack of progress and stipulates against the generation of BIP submissions by AI/LLM technologies, enhancing the clarity and functionality of the BIP process. The email exchange reveals a culture of collaboration and appreciation within the Bitcoin Development Mailing List group, as evidenced by Ruben's commendation of Murch for his diligent work on drafting a document or proposal. This interaction underscores the high value placed on meticulous effort and community input in the development process. Additionally, Greg's feedback during the discussion on the BIP editing process brings to light concerns about the listing of current editors within the BIP text itself, suggesting a need for a more dynamic approach to prevent the list from becoming outdated. A correction was made in the discussion regarding the activation process for Process BIPs, clarifying that BIP 2 already outlined a procedure for moving from Draft to Active status, contrary to previous claims. This correction emphasizes adherence to established guidelines for achieving rough consensus within the community. Further analysis of BIP 3 highlighted several areas for refinement, such as the inclusion of a log to document objections and their resolutions, involving non-author editors to confirm rough consensus, and providing clearer explanations for number assignment denials. These recommendations aim to improve transparency, neutrality, and the overall effectiveness of the BIP process. Lastly, Melvin Carvalho's review of the BIP 3 proposal sheds light on specific concerns and suggestions for improvement. These include ensuring BIPs' relevance to multiple Bitcoin projects, addressing the use of AI/LLM in content creation, reevaluating the roles of authors and deputies, and refining the requirements for reference implementations and public discussion. Carvalho's critique also touches on terminology, the role of BIP editors, and the clarity of the proposal's rationale, highlighting areas for further discussion to enhance BIP 3's alignment with community needs and expectations.
